messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): I wonder how this WebKit bug came into being: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=48593
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:54): was someone trying to be helpful instead of reading specs?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:54): or did someone accidentally lump comment nodes together with text and CDATA nodes in a branch condition somewhere?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:56): sort of curious what happens with processing instructions now
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I have a simple patch for the xmlparser that I've also been meaning to ask you about
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:04): for addressing http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=805

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:05): dude is getting a "Error: The shape attribute on the a element is obsolete" for all a elements in his source despite not having any shape attribute on any of them
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:06): due to the fact that he's selected "XML: load external entities"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:06): so the parser is reading the DTD and defaulting the shape attribute to "rect"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:06): because that's what the DTD requires
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:07): but it's not something that's obvious at all to most end users
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:07): http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=11124 -- consider doing A; considered A and rejected it; omg TrackerIssue!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:08): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: hence the proposed patch: https://bitbucket.org/validator/xmlparser-patches/qseries?apply=t&qs_apply=warn-default-attrs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:08): editorial stuff that ends up as TrackerIssue is soooo... *yawn*
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:11): if somebody adds the TrackerRequest keyword, the decision policy requires the chairs to issue-ify it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:13): though I guess that's not one that seems like it should merit much of everybody else's attention
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): on the patch
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:14): cool
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:14): thanks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:14): wording is OK?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:14): no tweaks to suggest?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:15): yes to OK. no tweaks to suggest.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:16): so what's the point of having multiple SSL cert classes below EV?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): aren't they equivalent to the weakest level for practical purposes anyway if they are presented the same way to the user?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): that is, what's the point of getting a class 3 cert if you can get the SSL indicator in browser UI using a class  1 cert?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:18): wonders why Netscape didn't build itself a business model by charging CAs for the root certs they shipped
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:24): Nobody would have paid to become a CA before SSL became popular enough to make it clear that it was worth it

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:25): and once SSL became popular enough, Netscape couldn't demand money from CAs because the CAs could say no and Netscape couldn't remove them without hurting their users who want their online banks to continue working
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:25): perhaps
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:30): CAs always seem kind of dodgy to me
d6e292711389fc8c3d399cd640fc8a40 (13:51): ping! Hixie

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:57): d6e292711389fc8c3d399cd640fc8a40, not sure what timezone you are on, but Hixie seems to have adjusted his schedule to be slightly more sane (he's in California)
d6e292711389fc8c3d399cd640fc8a40 (13:57): and I thought as much
d6e292711389fc8c3d399cd640fc8a40 (13:58): I was just hopeful
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:58): Australia; tough :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:12): "For the first time, we included HTML5 H.264 video directly in posts." -- IEBlog
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:21): what is Mounir's IRC nick again?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:24): ah right
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:24): so why can't the comma thing only be relevant for serialization?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:25): it seems you don't want to remove it while the user is still editing
92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (14:26): what do you mean?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:28): your solution 1 would do that
92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (14:31): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: my solution 1 would remove the last comma in the DOM if there is nothing else than trailing whitespaces after it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:34): tried https://github.com/aredridel/html5 -- HTML5 parser for node.js -- and seems usable
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:34): though slow
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:34): slower than html5lib
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:35): 1m47.097s to parse the HTML5 spec on my machine, versus 0m51.145s with html5lib
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:35): 92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d, but the user would still have it?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:36): I guess it depends on what the field looks like :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:36): ideally it probably does not involve the user actually having to type commas

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:36): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: what's the most popular XML tree representation for node.js? Does aredriedel's parser use whatever the most popular tree is?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:37): should learn about node.js some day
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:38): I wonder if the GWT compiler manages to produce code that has few enough browser deps to work on node.js
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:38): yeah, would be great if it did
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: dunno which tree APIs are available now for node and which ones others might be using
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:39): but things are still changing pretty rapidly in node-land
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:40): but aredridel seems to have his head in the right place
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:41): see the "Interesting features" part of https://github.com/aredridel/html5#readme
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:41): Streaming parser: You can pass parser.parse an EventEmitter and the parser will keep adding data as it's received.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:41): HTML5 parsing algorithm. If you find something this can't parse, I'll want to know about it. It should make sense out of anything a browser can.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:42): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: anyway, I think hober is probably a lot more current than me around the state of the parsing and document API stuff in node
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:42): jsdom
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:46): window = jsdom.createWindow(null, null, {parser: HTML5});
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:46): jsdom.jQueryify(window, 'deps/jquery/dist/jquery.js', function(window, jquery) {
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:46): Script.runInNewContext('jQuery("p").append("<b>Hi!</b>")', window);
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:46): sys.puts(window.document.innerHTML);
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:46): interesting

92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (14:46): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: if there is a UI for autocompletion for example, it needs to know which token is currently edited so when you select on item in the list a comma needs to be added
92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (14:46): that way you can select multiple values one after the other
92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (14:47): but this comma should not block the form submission
92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (14:47): and i don't see anything changed in the specs to make this happen
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:48): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: is that jsdom a DOM impl. in pure JS?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:48): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: does it do Level 2?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:48): yeah, it does now, I think
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:49): did not initially
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:49): but was added within the last few months
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:49): well, then it should be easy to use the V.nu parser on node.js
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:49): might be worth trying if it already runs as-is
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:50): see https://github.com/tmpvar/jsdom/blob/master/example/browser/browser.js
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:50): assuming node.js has setTimeout()
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:50): it does
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:50): it has everything that V8 has currently
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:51): I really should play with node.js some time
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:51): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:51): I definitely recommend it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:51): just hard to keep up with because things are getting changed/added daily
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:51): embarrassment of riches
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:52): #Node.js channel is a good place to reach some of the core node devs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:52): ok. I implemented duplicate error suppression for unclose elements
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:52): oh cool
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:52): you fast
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:52): I'll get it pushed.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:54): 92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d, how does the "latest values" concept not work?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:55): although it does not seem entirely clear how everything fits together :/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:55): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: writing code in Java without proper unit tests is so much faster than writing C++ with unit tests.
67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:00): Hi. Is this a channel to discuss the HTML5 spec doc on w3c site?

92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (15:01): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: for what i understand, the "latest values" concept doesn't take into account the case where the last value is the empty string after removing whitespaces
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:01): 67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1: Yes
92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d (15:01): so "a, b, c, " will be changed to "a,b,c,"

67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:02): Philip tnx. One sentence says: "Another example of the mark element is highlighting parts of a document that are matching some search string. If someone looked at a document, and the server knew that the user was searching for the word "kitten", then the server might return the document with one paragraph modified as follows" I remember Google has been granted a patent for doing something very similar
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:04): 92fd44f6f5704793df83313ba59be99d, is that actually a value though? hmm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:05): I guess it should remove those that are empty from latest values just in case
67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:08): it is just an example of use of mark tag, but it sounds like google's patent
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:09): 67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1, well, the W3C has a Patent Policy and Google is a member of the group
67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:10): im just a developer not a lawyer
67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:11): Annevk so there is ok to have that example on spec right?
67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:11): s/there is/is it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:13): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: have you ever done any benchmarking with the GWT version of the parser?

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:13): well, I'm not a lawyer either, but the basic idea is that if a Member organization holds a patent on some technology in a specification, which the Member organization helps developing through a W3C Working Group, the Member organization gives away a RF-license for said patent for everyone to use
67bafbfed8bfdf46d032f1ca4fc0cfd1 (15:15): annvek cool I was not aware of that. Tnx! Have to go. See you all later.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:21): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I have but JS engines and JS-to-DOM glue have improved since then
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:22): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: back in the Firefox 3.5 days, either DOM/layout dominated or the code didn't get traced
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:22): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: because back then tracer on vs tracer off showed no difference
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:23): I see
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:24): well, current node -- 0.3 -- is up to date with latest V8 I think
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:24): so in addition to the performance stuff that was there already, it has the crankshaft optimizations that were added more recently
